title: Campaigners lose bid to get court order forcing Boris Johnson to delay Brexit
text:

Campaigners have lost a bid to get a court order which would force Boris Johnson to delay Brexit.

Edinburgh's Court of Session ruled against the bid today, saying it had been assured the Prime Minister will obey the law.

The case focused on how Boris Johnson might be forced to obey a law that says he must ask the EU for a three-month Brexit delay on October 19.

Campaigners were trying to get two orders from the Court of Session that would have forced the Prime Minister to obey the so-called 'Benn Act'.

The first would have prevented him "taking any action that would undermine or frustrate" the Act - such as delaying his 'delay letter', or issuing a parallel letter to the EU asking them not to grant an extension.

The second order would have directly ordered Mr Johnson to ensure the delay letter was signed and sent before 3pm on October 19.

But the UK government won over the court by promising, in writing, that it would obey the Benn Act after all.

(Image: Getty Images)

Lord Pentland, sitting at the Court of Session's Outer House, today said that promise was enough - and refused to grant the court orders.

He said it was "neither necessary nor appropriate" to grant the orders because "there can be no doubt that [PM] now accepts that he must comply with the requirements of the 2019 Act and has affirmed that he intends to do so."

The judge added: "The court should not pronounce coercive orders (or decree for interdict) unless it has been established on the basis of cogent evidence that it is truly necessary for such orders to be granted.

"In my opinion, that has not been done in the present case."

It comes after mixed messages from the PM over whether he would try to bend or get round the law.

Last week the government told Scotland's highest court Mr Johnson would obey the so-called 'Benn Act' - after the Attorney General privately threatened to resign.

Yet the Prime Minister then contradicted that by tweeting: " New deal or no deal - but no delay." And Cabinet allies refused to confirm he would send the crucial letter to the EU asking for delay.

An appeal may now be expected as soon as tomorrow in the case.

The Daily Telegraph today reports the PM is willing to fight in the Supreme Court to force a no-deal Brexit on October 31.

One source said Mr Johnson must find a legal mechanism allowing him to say "I am literally not going to write that letter".

They added: "The real drama would be if Boris were in court calling it 'the Surrender Act'. He would almost be happy if the judge said 'you can't call it that'."

A Downing Street spokesman said today: “The Prime Minister has been clear throughout that we will obey the law. We are leaving on October 31. The manner in which this policy is lawfully achieved is a matter for the government.”

Boris Johnson will not have to write the delay letter if he manages to secure a Brexit deal at an EU summit on October 17.

But hopes of any deal are fading fast after EU sources rejected his new proposal for "two borders" in Northern Ireland.

French President Emmanuel Macron gave the UK a deadline of this Friday to compromise - as the PM ramped up his no-deal Brexit rhetoric.

(Image: REUTERS)

In a phone call last night, the French President signalled EU chiefs would decide this week whether the UK had moved enough to strike a deal.

The PM was talking to more EU leaders today while his top Brexit advisor David Frost and Brexit Secretary Steve Barclay will spend the week on a whirlwind tour of European capitals.

A senior No 10 source said: “The UK has made a big, important offer but it’s time for the Commission to show a willingness to compromise too. If not the UK will leave with no deal”.

(Image: Hollie Adams)

(Image: Rex)

The petitioners launched today's legal case in the belief that Downing Street cannot be trusted to abide by the law.

The 'Benn Act', passed by Westminster last month, requires the Prime Minister to ask the EU for a Brexit extension to January 31 if Parliament does not agree to any withdrawal deal by October 19.

Legal action - led by businessman and founder of the firm Ecotricity Vince Dale, SNP MP Joanna Cherry QC and Jolyon Maugham QC - was launched at the Outer House of Edinburgh's Court of Session.

It sought to create an order which would force Mr Johnson to send the letter and prohibits him from frustrating the Act's purpose.

(Image: Getty Images)

This included banning him from asking EU member states to deny the letter's request or by sending an additional letter which contradicts it.

Aidan O'Neill QC, representing the campaigners behind the legal action, claimed Mr Johnson's previous statements go against what he has said to the court through the documents.

He referred to promises made by the Prime Minister that he would rather be "dead in a ditch" than send a letter requesting an extension, and that the UK will leave on October 31 "do or die".
description: Edinburgh's Court of Session ruled against the bid for two court orders - as the PM considers forcing the issue to a Supreme Court showdown
